716733f-a.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716733f-a.text:
The Bowery, west side, between Bayard and Canal Streets,
showing the old Thalia Theatre and its adjoining Atlantic Gardens.
On the right margin is the original Citixens Savings Bank.
1910
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE
Neg E 32
Neg. ~ 2,85 (rAi oeg)

716610f-a.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716610f-a.text:
45 Bayard Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of the Bowery. Building
shown is a frame house, with a stucco front.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 14.
CREDIT LINE ILPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

716735f-a.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716735f-a.text:
(1)
Bowery, west side, north from and including Bayard, to, but not
including Canal Streets. The upper stories only are shown as the
Third Ave., Elevated and the Manhattan Bridge Plasa obstructs the
full view.
December 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the lower part of the Thalia
Theatre.
December 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, as No. 2, but at a later date.
July 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

716734f.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716734f.text:
The Bowery, west side, between Bayard and Canal Streets,
showin the Atlantic Gardens. Adioining on the left is the
Bowery Theatre which became the Thalia in 1879. Note the tele-
graph poles and the absence of the 3rd Avenue ''El'' structure.
The latter, erected in 1878 evidently dates this photo.
prior to 1878
Gift of Urbrock Collection
MAY BE REPRODU:ED

1508987-b.title: Bowery Street #28 - Bayard Street
1508987-b.folder: Bowery Street #28 - Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY

716739f-c.title: Manhattan: Bowery - Bayard Street
716739f-c.text:
(3)
The same as No. 2, but at an earlier date. The Thalia Theatre, as
shown here, was erected in 1826 as the Bowery Theatre; the Mayor laying
the corner stone in May and it being opened in October of that year. It
was destroyed by fire four times. First on May 26, 1828, when it was re-
built and reopened in 90 days. It was destroyed again September 22, 1836;
for the third time, February 8, 1838; and last on April 25, 1845. It
retained the name Bowery until 1879, when it was re-christened the Thalia.
Its final and last fire occured on June 15, 1929 and the remains disfigured
the area for several years. Today (1937) this old landmark is completely
(9ne, a low business structure occupying the site. The Bull's Head, a
tavern used for the sale of cattle stood on this site from prior to 1763
to 1826, when it was taken down.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

1508987-a.title: Bowery Street #28 - Bayard Street

716607f-a.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716607f-a.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, west from but not including the Bowery. This view
is taken during the dedication of the Gee How Oak Tong Buildin2.
(A family brotherhood,) at No. 62 Bayard Street.
September 3, 1927,
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same showing, Bayard Street, north side, west from but not
including Elizabeth Street.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same as No. 1, but more inclusive and showing the Bowery.
September 25, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

716606f-b.title: Manhattan: Bayard Street - Bowery
716606f-b.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, south side, at the Bowery, showing an old hip-roofed
house (No. 29 Bowery), at the S.E. corner. Shown on the Bowery is the
Third Ave. Elevated Line.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Arumbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
A side view of No. 29 Bowery, which is at the S.E. corner.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
